subject: Re: [junit] Learning Junit
msgSnippet: ... Welcome to the wonderful world of JUnit! There are many useful websites for the JUnit user, but perhaps the two main ones are http://www.junit.org/ and
messageBody:
On 3/29/06, srikanth master <chinna_567@...> wrote:
> Hi,
>
> This is srikanth working as a software engineer for a
> private firm.
> I want to learn Junit language for an assignment
> here.
>
> It would be of a great help if you forward me some
> tutorials or e books on this language.
>
>
> Appreciate your help on this.
>
> Regards,
> Srikanth

Welcome to the wonderful world of JUnit!

There are many useful websites for the JUnit user, but perhaps the two
main ones are http://www.junit.org/ and http://www.google.com/.

The JUnit site maintains a lot of useful information and links to
other resources. Many of the articles there are directed towards the
beginner and will help you greatly as you learn about JUnit. There is
even a link on the site called "Getting Started" that will take you to
a page full of useful information for those who wish to learn to use
JUnit.

Google is useful when there's something you need, but don't know what
it is. Just type a description in, press enter and see how much help
it can be. I've found quite a few useful things that way. Another tip
with Google is to search on the specific error message that you have,
often you'll find forum discussions about that exact error, with a
good chance of a solution being given as well.

As you learn and start having questions, you will also find the JUnit
FAQ very helpful. The questions that it answers really are the
frequent ones that most of us had asked or wondered about and Mike
Clark does a wonderful job of collating it. Here is a link:

http://junit.sourceforge.net/doc/faq/faq.htm

When you are ready to start asking more questions on the JUnit mailing
list, please consider following all of the advice in Eric Raymond's
very helpful document: "How to ask questions the smart way", available
at his website. Here is a link:

http://www.catb.org/~esr/faqs/smart-questions.html

As far as books are concerned, I recommend Pragmatic Unit Testing by
Hunt and Thomas for beginners. JUnit recipes by Rainsberger is good
once you're past the basics. There are other good books out there, but
these are my recommendations.

I hope that this helps.

Simon

--
www.simonpeter.org
